content.raw:
Fair enough, I understand why it is less expensive to return _a_ AABB rather than _the minimal_ AABB, and this seems to be a compromise that other software is making as well.

> The purpose of an AABB is just to provide a first-order approximation for quickly culling pairs of objects that are obviously not in contact.

Yeah that's objective for the physics engine, but consumers of ign-gazebo, such as SubT's comms, may be using it for something else. I think we just need to be aware of the limitations.

In fact, for those use cases, I suspect even an OBB in the link's frame may be good enough, saving us the extra projection of the OBB to the world frame, but we'd need to also store the box pose besides its min/max values.

> the maximum inflation is only ~41% of the radius anyway

Yeah that's true for the sphere, but I can imagine long thin cylinders positioned in such a way that the inflation is close to 100% - but that's just stretching corner cases to extreme :smile: 

In any case, if we eventually need the minimal AABB, I think that calculation doesn't even need to be done within ign-physics. An ign-gazebo plugin would just need the `common::Mesh`, special cases for primitives, and a lot of computational power :smile:
content.html:
Fair enough, I understand why it is less expensive to return a AABB rather than the minimal AABB, and this seems to be a compromise that other software is making as well.

The purpose of an AABB is just to provide a first-order approximation for quickly culling pairs of objects that are obviously not in contact.

Yeah that's objective for the physics engine, but consumers of ign-gazebo, such as SubT's comms, may be using it for something else. I think we just need to be aware of the limitations.

In fact, for those use cases, I suspect even an OBB in the link's frame may be good enough, saving us the extra projection of the OBB to the world frame, but we'd need to also store the box pose besides its min/max values.

the maximum inflation is only ~41% of the radius anyway

Yeah that's true for the sphere, but I can imagine long thin cylinders positioned in such a way that the inflation is close to 100% - but that's just stretching corner cases to extreme

In any case, if we eventually need the minimal AABB, I think that calculation doesn't even need to be done within ign-physics. An ign-gazebo plugin would just need the common::Mesh, special cases for primitives, and a lot of computational power

pull_request.title: Correct the calculation of AABB transformations and give frame semantics to AABB types

pullrequest.title: Correct the calculation of AABB transformations and give frame semantics to AABB types

content.raw:
What it boils down to is the axis aligned bounding box is agnostic to the underlying shape. As far as the physics engine is concerned, this sphere may as well be a cube. When the shape is rotated, it acts as though the cube is rotated, because otherwise \(as Nate points out [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/71/correct-the-calculation-of-aabb/diff#comment-93514430)\), the physics engine would need to recalculate the bounding box from scratch for the new orientation \(which can be very expensive\).

The purpose of an AABB is just to provide a first-order approximation for quickly culling pairs of objects that are obviously not in contact. The inflation that we see from these transformations may result in false positives for that first-order test, but being able to perform that first-order test as quickly as possible will still pay off handsomely in large environments with many objects.

In the special case of a sphere we could theoretically eliminate that inflation without loss of precision, but the amount of machinery we would need to handle that one special case isn’t worth it \(at least in my opinion\) when the maximum inflation is only ~41% of the radius anyway, and the second-order test for spheres is usually super duper fast anyway.
content.html:
What it boils down to is the axis aligned bounding box is agnostic to the underlying shape. As far as the physics engine is concerned, this sphere may as well be a cube. When the shape is rotated, it acts as though the cube is rotated, because otherwise (as Nate points out here), the physics engine would need to recalculate the bounding box from scratch for the new orientation (which can be very expensive).

The purpose of an AABB is just to provide a first-order approximation for quickly culling pairs of objects that are obviously not in contact. The inflation that we see from these transformations may result in false positives for that first-order test, but being able to perform that first-order test as quickly as possible will still pay off handsomely in large environments with many objects.

In the special case of a sphere we could theoretically eliminate that inflation without loss of precision, but the amount of machinery we would need to handle that one special case isn’t worth it (at least in my opinion) when the maximum inflation is only ~41% of the radius anyway, and the second-order test for spheres is usually super duper fast anyway.

content.raw:
From: https://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/131833/when_two_hearts_collide_.php?print=1, I think we could also use the extremities of the OOBB to compute the minimal AABB.

" it’s possible to transform only those extreme points by the current orientation and get a new bounding box. In other words, I can take the vertices of the object’s OBB and use the maximum and minimum of those positions to create a new AABB"
content.html:
From: https://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/131833/when_two_hearts_collide_.php?print=1, I think we could also use the extremities of the OOBB to compute the minimal AABB.

" it’s possible to transform only those extreme points by the current orientation and get a new bounding box. In other words, I can take the vertices of the object’s OBB and use the maximum and minimum of those positions to create a new AABB"

content.raw:
This feels weird to me as well. Admittedly, I haven't gone through the whole code, but just reading the comment, it sounds like the result is not the sphere's AABB, but the AABB of the sphere's locally aligned BB?

In other words, can we call it a bounding box if it's not tangential to the shape anymore?
content.html:
This feels weird to me as well. Admittedly, I haven't gone through the whole code, but just reading the comment, it sounds like the result is not the sphere's AABB, but the AABB of the sphere's locally aligned BB?

In other words, can we call it a bounding box if it's not tangential to the shape anymore?

pull_request.title: Correct the calculation of AABB transformations and give frame semantics to AABB types

update.description: This PR fixes the transforming of AABB types and gives them frame semantics so that AABB objects can be expressed relative to any coordinate frame and transformed between coordinate frames.
update.title: Correct the calculation of AABB transformations and give frame semantics to AABB types

content.raw:
One option to consider: Right now the default frame for `shape->GetAxisAlignedBoundingBox()` is the world frame. We could make that default to the shape's local frame instead so that users would call `shape->GetAxisAlignedBoundingBox(FrameID::World())` if they want the result to be in the world frame.

I’m fine with either way, but I thought I’d put that out there for discussion.
content.html:
One option to consider: Right now the default frame for shape->GetAxisAlignedBoundingBox() is the world frame. We could make that default to the shape's local frame instead so that users would call shape->GetAxisAlignedBoundingBox(FrameID::World()) if they want the result to be in the world frame.

I’m fine with either way, but I thought I’d put that out there for discussion.
